questions.question: How does chest wall compliance in an infant differ from that of an adult?
options: An adult’s chest wall compliance is lower than an infant’s.
An adult’s chest wall compliance is higher than an infant’s.
An adult’s chest wall compliance is the same as an infant’s.
An adult’s chest wall compliance is dissimilar to that of an infant’s.
questions.rationale: Infants have higher chest wall compliance than adults, especially premature infants.

questions.question: Why is nasal congestion a serious threat to young infants?
options: Their noses are small in diameter.
Infants become dehydrated when mouth breathing.
Their epiglottis is proportionally greater than that of an adult.
questions.rationale: Infants up to 2–3 months old are obligatory nose breathers.

questions.question: The risk for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) decreases for premature infants born between how many weeks of gestation?
Which type of croup is most common?
What is the chief predisposing factor for RDS of the newborn?
questions.rationale: Prematurity is the leading risk factor.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of RDS of the newborn?
What is the main problem resulting from RDS?
questions.rationale: Atelectasis with hypoxemia and difficulty inflating alveoli.

questions.question: Which sequence occurs after atelectasis in RDS?
options: Increased pulmonary vascular resistance, atelectasis, hypoperfusion

questions.question: Which statement about advances in RDS treatment is incorrect?
options: Administering glucocorticoids to women before preterm labor accelerates fetal lung maturation.
Administering oxygen to mothers during preterm labor increases fetal oxygenation.
Exogenous surfactant can be instilled into an endotracheal tube of premature infants.
questions.rationale: Oxygen to mother does not treat fetal RDS.

questions.question: Bronchiolitis in the first year of life is most often caused by:
questions.rationale: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most common cause of bronchiolitis in infants.
